title: Thomas Duarte
text:
Thomas James Duarte (born March 30, 1995) is an American former professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="UCLA%20Bruins%20football">UCLA Bruins</a>, and earned second-team <a href="List%20of%20All-Pac-12%20Conference%20football%20teams">all-conference</a> honors in the <a href="Pac-12%20Conference">Pac-12</a> as a junior in 2015. After foregoing his final year of college eligibility to enter the <a href="2016%20NFL%20Draft">2016 NFL Draft</a>, he was selected by the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> in the seventh round. He spent most of his two seasons with the Dolphins on their <a href="practice%20squad">practice squad</a>. He played for the <a href="Arizona%20Hotshots">Arizona Hotshots</a> of the <a href="Alliance%20of%20American%20Football">Alliance of American Football</a> (AAF) in 2019, but the league suspended operations midseason in its only season.
Early life.
Duarte was born in <a href="Fullerton%2C%20California">Fullerton, California</a> to Timothy and Deborah Duarte. Growing up, Duarte was always big. At age 10, he was and . He played <a href="tackle%20%28football%20move%29">tackle</a> football for a year against players who were three to four years older. However, he went back to playing <a href="flag%20football">flag football</a> after the players his size entered high school, and he became too big to play <a href="Pop%20Warner%20football">Pop Warner football</a> due to their weight restrictions.
Duarte returned to tackle football as a high school freshman at <a href="Mater%20Dei%20High%20School%20%28Santa%20Ana%2C%20California%29">Mater Dei High</a> in <a href="Santa%20Ana%2C%20California">Santa Ana</a>. As a senior, he had 58 <a href="reception%20%28gridiron%20football%29">receptions</a> with 1,025 <a href="receiving%20yards">receiving yards</a> and 15 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s and averaged 18 yards a catch. He also played on defense at <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a>, and had 42 tackles, 10 <a href="quarterback%20sack">quarterback sack</a>s, three <a href="interception">interception</a>s and a <a href="fumble%20recovery">fumble recovery</a>. He was named Player of the Year by the "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>" and Offensive Player of the Year by "<a href="The%20Orange%20County%20Register">The Orange County Register</a>".
The son of a <a href="Mexican-American">Mexican-American</a> father and <a href="Japanese-American">Japanese-American</a> mother, Duarte was one of the rare high-profile <a href="college%20recruit">college recruit</a>s to be of <a href="Asian%20people">Asian</a> descent. He was rated a four-star prospect and capable of playing <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a>, <a href="H-back">H-back</a>, or <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> in college. He decided to attend the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Los%20Angeles">University of California, Los Angeles</a> (UCLA), his mother's alma mater.
College career.
Duarte struggled with hamstring injuries during his first two seasons with the <a href="UCLA%20Bruins">Bruins</a>. In his junior year in <a href="2015%20UCLA%20Bruins%20football%20team">2015</a>, he was a second-team <a href="List%20of%20All-Pac-12%20Conference%20football%20teams">All-Pac-12</a> selection at tight end. He finished the season with 53 receptions for 872 yards, and led the team with 10 touchdown catches. His 16.6 yards per reception was the highest among UCLA receivers with 10 or more catches. After the season, he opted to forego his final year of college eligibility and enter the <a href="2016%20NFL%20Draft">2016 NFL Draft</a>.
Professional career.
Duarte was the top performer in his position on the 40-yard dash, vertical jump, broad jump, 3 cone drill and the 20-yard shuttle in 2016 NFL Combine.
Miami Dolphins.
Duarte was drafted by the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> in the seventh round, 231st overall, in the <a href="2016%20NFL%20Draft">2016 NFL Draft</a>. On September 3, 2016, he was released by the Dolphins as part of final roster cuts. He was later signed to their <a href="practice%20squad">practice squad</a>. He was promoted to the active roster on November 5. The next day, he was in for two <a href="Snap%20%28gridiron%20football%29">snaps</a> in a 27–23 win over the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a> in his only action for the season.
On September 2, 2017, Duarte was waived by the Dolphins and was signed to the practice squad the next day. He was promoted to the active roster on December 20 to replace tight end <a href="Julius%20Thomas">Julius Thomas</a>, who was placed on <a href="injured%20reserve">injured reserve</a>.
During the 2018 offseason, Duarte missed part of the team's training program with a shoulder injury. He returned for training camp but was among the Dolphins final cuts before the <a href="2018%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">2018 season</a> after he failed to supplant veterans <a href="MarQueis%20Gray">MarQueis Gray</a> and <a href="A.%20J.%20Derby">A. J. Derby</a>.
Los Angeles Chargers.
On September 3, 2018, Duarte was signed to the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Chargers">Los Angeles Chargers</a>' practice squad. He was released on September 25, 2018.
Arizona Hotshots.
In 2019, Duarte joined the <a href="Arizona%20Hotshots">Arizona Hotshots</a> of the <a href="Alliance%20of%20American%20Football">Alliance of American Football</a>. He caught eight passes for 111 yards and two touchdowns before the league suspended operations mid-season.
Carolina Panthers.
Duarte signed with the <a href="Carolina%20Panthers">Carolina Panthers</a> on April 8, 2019. He was waived on May 13, 2019.
Atlanta Falcons.
On August 24, 2019, Duarte was signed by the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a>. He was waived on August 31, 2019.
